title: 111_hr5710
content: The Act is titled the "National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Reauthorization Act of 2010." It amends the purpose of the Act. The National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Act of 2005 is amended to establish State-administered controlled substance monitoring systems to provide health care providers with timely prescription history information for identifying patients at risk for addiction and to give law enforcement access to prescription history information. The National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Act of 2005 is amended to establish State-administered controlled substance monitoring systems to provide prescription history information for investigating drug diversion and prescribing practices. Amendments are made to the Controlled Substance Monitoring Program. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include adding a provision for maintaining and operating existing State-controlled substance monitoring programs. Minimum requirements for State criteria are also outlined, with the Secretary responsible for updating them as needed. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include updating State-controlled substance monitoring programs to improve or maintain public health and safety. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act include enhancing State-controlled substance monitoring programs by establishing, improving, or maintaining interoperability and implementing timelines for full interoperability. The Secretary will monitor State efforts in achieving interoperability and redistribute any returned funds among remaining grantees. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act require states to comply with a formula for grants and establish, improve, or maintain controlled substance monitoring programs. This includes removing references to implementing or improving and replacing them with establishing, improving, or maintaining in various subsections. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act require states to establish, improve, or maintain controlled substance monitoring programs. States receiving grants must provide necessary data for evaluation and reporting to the Secretary. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act mandate states to establish controlled substance monitoring programs. States receiving grants must facilitate prescriber use of the monitoring system and educate them on its benefits. The amendments to the Public Health Service Act require states to establish controlled substance monitoring programs. Preference may be given to states with approved applications, existing monitoring programs, or those making efforts to meet requirements. The Public Health Service Act amendments require states to establish controlled substance monitoring programs and authorize appropriations of $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2011 and $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Public Health Service Act amendments were passed by the House of Representatives on September 23, 2010.
